%s' % (method, expires, urllib.parse.unquote(path)), self.digest).hexdigest() parms['temp_url_sig'] = sig return parms def test_GET_prefix(self): dlo = self.env.manifest_container.file( self.env.prefix + Utils.create_name()) dlo.write( '', hdrs={'X-Object-Manifest': '%s/%s' % (self.env.segments_container, self.env.prefix)}) expires = int(time()) + 86400 parms = self.tempurl_params( 'GET', expires, self.env.conn.make_path(dlo.path), self.env.tempurl_key, self.env.prefix) contents = dlo.read( parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True}) self.assertEqual(len(contents), 2 * 1024 * 1024) # GET tempurls also allow HEAD requests self.assertTrue(dlo.info( parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True})) def test_GET_segments_not_prefixed(self): dlo = self.env.manifest_container.file( self.env.prefix + Utils.create_name()) dlo.write( '', hdrs={'X-Object-Manifest': '%s/%s' % (self.env.segments_container, self.env.non_prefix)}) expires = int(time()) + 86400 parms = self.tempurl_params( 'GET', expires, self.env.conn.make_path(dlo.path), self.env.tempurl_key, self.env.prefix) contents = dlo.read( parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True}) self.assertEqual(len(contents), 2 * 1024 * 1024) # Make sure we can read it. contents = dlo.read() self.assertEqual(len(contents), 2 * 1024 * 1024) # PUT tempurls also allow HEAD requests self.assertTrue(dlo.info( parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True})) def head_test(seg, raises_401=True): if raises_401: with self.assertRaises(ResponseError) as resp_err: seg.info(parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True}) self.assertEqual(resp_err.exception.status, 401) else: self.assertTrue(seg.info(parms=parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True})) # Can we use HEAD requests to search other containers we shouldn't # have access to? for segment, err in ((self.env.seg1, True), (self.env.seg3, True), (self.env.non_existent_seg, True), (self.env.local_seg1, False), (self.env.local_seg3, True), (self.env.local_non_existent_seg, True)): head_test(segment, err) class TestTempurlPrefixDloUTF8(Base2, TestTempurlPrefixDlo): pass

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit 1.6.0 and cap Sphinx on Python2

There's a regression[0] in bandit 1.6.0 which causes bandit to stop
respecting excluded directories, and our tests throw a bunch of
violations. Blacklist this version, but allow newer versions as there is
already a pull request[1] to fix it, and I expect it will be included in
the next release.

Also fix the requirements job which was broken by
https://review.opendev.org/657890 adding a cap on Sphinx on Python 2.

[0] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/issues/488
[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

Change-Id: Ieabcd4e8c5e5354125a63e89b9b60931c760858a
(cherry picked from commit 011fa22c42506e63229cca7e5fc65f81b6e0aabf)

commit_message:
Set concurrency control spec to release independent

The specification "Mechanism to Prevent Race Conditions Spec"
is release independent. It lays out a framework for
designing manila APIs and resource state machines to prevent
race conditions. Some of the work items have not been
completed, and will be addressed in Train and future
releases.

Change-Id: I4f9e754676507af417ccae920487d35d86b1ae29

commit_message:
Remove deprecated keystone::federation::openidc params

These params has been deprecated. Also removes the keystone_url
behavior where it doesn't fallback on keystone::public_endpoint
anymore.

commit_message:
Share and back end capabilities improvements

Move Stein spec to Train.

- Create new common capabilities for storage_protocol
  and shrinking_support and modify drivers to report
  these capabilities.
- Allow the shrink API to fail fast
  if the share is created on a back end that doesn't support
  it.
- Allow the pool-list to reliably report storage_protocol
  for all back ends/storage pools.

APIImpact
Partially-implements: bp storage-proto-enhancement
Partially-implements: bp make-share-shrinking-support-a-capability

Change-Id: I5ae65456d13bb421765ea6a77fcab21320af25c1

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I32f90005a31b1ce844feffc0fed0f46ff57976be

commit_message:
Fix-up standard rabbit config in init.pp

This makes magnum use the same parameters as other puppet-openstack
modules, and add unit testing just like done in the Aodh module.

Change-Id: Ib877aef6d04ab45abe43eb72d3b58db45dcb5bd0

commit_message:
Remove paste

Removes all the deprecated resources for paste
support in keystone which we notified about in Stein.

Keystone doesn't use paste so it doesn't work in Stein
either so we remove it for Train.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658546/
Change-Id: Id7dfdf2f5cb9453044d39812b7cbd216b7f3eb50

commit_message:
Move unimplemented specifications to separate folder

This cleans up stuff so users and documentation
folks can be sure that targeted specifications
have been implemented in one form or another.

Change-Id: I0a8daab3ba55ff43b3db8433077eb667b84a5ee2

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-16 16:30:55.000000000', 'files': ['setup.cfg', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tricircleclient/commit/c214bece68f3f570a1a443b7257c470ed316e18c', 'message': 'Dropping the py35 testing

Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I188923dc2896866c9fa955678d9564501fc0caae

commit_message:
Verify image checksums after upload

The OpenStack Infra team noticed that nodepool (via openstack sdk)
uploaded an invalid image. This prevented node boots from completing
successfully and would have been caught by a simple checksum check step.

Add this step to prevent openstacksdk users from attempting to use bad
image uploads.

Change-Id: If9eafdd7b60098ed5bbc37ad06757a6f7e348b4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/11/657411/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'md5'in image_kwargs or 'sha256' in image_kwargs: # Verify that the hash computed remotely matches the local # value md5 = image_kwargs.get('md5') sha256 = image_kwargs.get('sha256') checksum = data['checksum'] data = self.get('/images/{id}'.format(id=image.id)) valid = checksum and (checksum == md5 or checksum == sha256) if not valid: raise Exception('Image checksum verification failed')

commit_message:
Support sriovdp arbitrary resource names

This patch adds ability to work with new sriov device plugin's
feature. This feature implies arbitrary names for resource.
So kuryr-kubernetes should also know about such resources.
Resources are listed in /etc/pcidp/config.json

If physnet_resource_mappings is not specified it's assumed
resource name is physnet.

Implements: blueprint move-to-new-sriovdp
Change-Id: I07c5338b6d5b431435c467b0c52b50fe3385a86a
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Fix rst errors in README

This fixes some rst formatting errors in the README file. The
readme is used as the package long description on pypi, and
they have recently enabled some checks that cause package
upload errors if there are formatting issues with the rst
content.

Change-Id: I3ff7a509c2b875606c985c87b61a63c5e15c1bda
(cherry picked from commit be83eae483cd864d882fc2ef209c8b1d1724a42b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-monascaclient refs/changes/74/658474/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================== This is a client library for Monasca built to interface with the Monasca API. It provides a Python API (the ``monascaclient`` module) and a command-line toolThe Monasca Client was written using the OpenStack Heat Python client as a framework.Requires:: pip - version >= 1.4. python get-pip.pyInstall It:: sudo pip install python-monascaclient Alternative Manual Install Steps:: cd <path to your python-monascaclient repo> sudo pip install -r requirements.txt python setup.py installInstall the tool dependencies:: sudo apt-get install python-pip python-virtualenv In the python-monascaclient source directory:: virtualenv --no-site-packages .venv source ./.venv/bin/activate pip install wheel python setup.py bdist_wheel pip install $(ls -1rt dist/*.whl | tail -1) --upgrade .. code-block:: console The monascaclient CLI needs the Monasca API endpoint url and the OS_AUTH_TOKEN to pass to the Monasca API RESTful interface. This is provided through environment or CLI parameters.Environmental variables can be sourced, or optionally passed in as CLI arguments. It is easiest to source them first and then use the CLI.When OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME is not set, then 'Default' is assumed. Alternatively IDs can be used instead of names.The Monasca API will treat the auth token as the tenant ID when Keystone is not enabled.
deleted_lines: ======================================= This is a client library for Monasca built to interface with the Monasca API. It provides a Python API (the ``monascaclient`` module) and a command-line toolThe Monasca Client was written using the OpenStack Heat Python client as a framework.Requires: - pip - version >= 1.4. python get-pip.pyInstall It: - sudo pip install python-monascaclient Alternative Manual Install Steps: - cd to your python-monascaclient repo - sudo pip install -r requirements.txt - python setup.py installInstall the tool dependencies sudo apt-get install python-pip python-virtualenv In the python-monascaclient source directory virtualenv --no-site-packages .venv source ./.venv/bin/activate pip install wheel python setup.py bdist_wheel pip install $(ls -1rt dist/*.whl | tail -1) --upgradeThe monascaclient CLI needs the Monasca API endpoint url and the OS_AUTH_TOKEN to pass to the Monasca API RESTful interface. This is provided through environment or CLI parameters.Environmental variables can be sourced, or optionally passed in as CLI arguments. It is easiest to source them first and then use the CLI.When OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME is not set, then 'Default' is assumed. Alternatively IDs can be used instead of names.The Monasca API will treat the auth token as the tenant ID when Keystone is not enabled.

commit_message:
Validate output of list_logical_volumes

The charm was checking for the zeroth value of the return value of
list_logical_volumes. However, if no logical volumes are found it
returns an empty list.

This change validates that the list has an entry.

Change-Id: I75a6b1dda15dd7c2cece8cfe97b28317b3d5162b
Partial-Bug: #1819382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charms.ceph refs/changes/55/659355/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-05-15 15:21:20.000000000', 'files': ['test-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.i18n/commit/810d60a5572c2f0053059132aeb63d81df93caed', 'message': 'Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: Id9a875393e42d9fc54d8c571d368180fec122839
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489
'}]
commit_message:
Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: Id9a875393e42d9fc54d8c571d368180fec122839
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

commit_message:
Blacklist Bandit 1.6.0 due to directory exclusion bug

Bandit 1.6.0 introduces a regression[0] with the -x option, a fix
is expected to be included in 1.6.1 soon.

[0] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/issues/488
[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

Change-Id: I110829ef960e3ee146f47871ef076491244bf4fa
Signed-off-by: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add the missing protocol for listener

According to the octavia api:
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/#listeners,
there miss the 'HTTPS' protocol.

Change-Id: I1d4857876a151148348ac79d554db2c4c6616559

commit_message:
Revert "Adding support for DPDK to openvswitch image"

This reverts commit a3d324b5b6a1ea9945a947776410953e3b423fdf.

This causes issues [1] when trying to use the built image inside
the OSH repos, which is a first step of a pipeline from image
building to full testing.

[1]: http://logs.openstack.org/66/658766/1/check/openstack-helm-infra-openstack-support/c35a41e/

Change-Id: Ie7432a205f957ed13cf3f502daf05d6b8cdb32b8

deleted_lines: #!/bin/bash # Tripleo CI functions # Revert a commit for tripleo ci # $1 : project name e.g. nova # $2 : hash id of commit to revert # $3 : bug id of reason for revert (used to skip revert if found in commit # that triggers ci). function temprevert { # Before reverting check to ensure this isn't the related fix if git --git-dir=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/${ZUUL_PROJECT#*/}/.git log -1 | grep -iE "bug.*$3" ; then echo "Skipping temprevert because bug fix $3 was found in git message." return 0 fi pushd $TRIPLEO_ROOT/$1 # Abort on fail so we're not left in a conflict state git revert --no-edit $2 || git revert --abort || true popd DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS="${DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS:-} $1" } # Pin to a commit for tripleo ci # $1 : project name e.g. nova # $2 : hash id of commit to pin too # $3 : bug id of reason for the pin (used to skip revert if found in commit # that triggers ci). function pin { # Before reverting check to ensure this isn't the related fix if git --git-dir=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/${ZUUL_PROJECT#*/}/.git log -1 | grep -iE "bug.*$3" ; then echo "Skipping pin because bug fix $3 was found in git message." return 0 fi pushd $TRIPLEO_ROOT/$1 git reset --hard $2 popd DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS="${DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS:-} $1" } # Cherry-pick a commit for tripleo ci # $1 : project name e.g. nova # $2 : Gerrit refspec to cherry pick # $3 : bug id of reason for the cherry pick (used to skip cherry pick if found # in commit that triggers ci). function cherrypick { local PROJ_NAME=$1 local REFSPEC=$2 # Before cherrypicking check to ensure this isn't the related fix if git --git-dir=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/${ZUUL_PROJECT#*/}/.git log -1 | grep -iE "bug.*$3" ; then echo "Skipping cherrypick because bug fix $3 was found in git message." return 0 fi pushd $TRIPLEO_ROOT/$PROJ_NAME git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/$PROJ_NAME "$REFSPEC" # Abort on fail so we're not left in a conflict state git cherry-pick FETCH_HEAD || git cherry-pick --abort popd DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS="${DELOREAN_BUILD_REFS:-} $1" # Export a DIB_REPOREF variable as well export DIB_REPOREF_${PROJ_NAME//-/_}=$REFSPEC } # echo's out a project name from a ref # $1 : e.g. openstack/nova:master:refs/changes/87/64787/3 returns nova function filterref { PROJ=${1%%:*} PROJ=${PROJ##*/} echo $PROJ } function layer_ci_repo { # Find the path to the trunk repository used TRUNKREPOUSED=$(grep -Eo "[0-9a-z]{2}/[0-9a-z]{2}/[0-9a-z]{40}_[0-9a-z]+" /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean.repo) # Layer the ci repository on top of it sudo wget http://$MY_IP:8766/current/delorean-ci.repo -O /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean-ci.repo # rewrite the baseurl in delorean-ci.repo as its currently pointing a https://trunk.rdoproject.org/.. sudo sed -i -e "s%baseurl=.*%baseurl=http://$MY_IP:8766/current/%" /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean-ci.repo sudo sed -i -e 's%priority=.*%priority=1%' /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean-ci.repo } function echo_vars_to_deploy_env { CALLER=$(caller) echo "# Written via echo_vars_to_deploy_env from $CALLER" >> $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-ci/deploy.env for VAR in NODEPOOL_CBS_CENTOS_PROXY NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR http_proxy INTROSPECT MY_IP no_proxy NODECOUNT OVERCLOUD_DEPLOY_ARGS OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS PACEMAKER SSH_OPTIONS STABLE_RELEASE TRIPLEO_ROOT TRIPLEO_SH_ARGS NETISO_V4 NETISO_V6 TOCI_JOBTYPE UNDERCLOUD_SSL UNDERCLOUD_HEAT_CONVERGENCE RUN_TEMPEST_TESTS RUN_PING_TEST JOB_NAME OVB UNDERCLOUD_IDEMPOTENT MULTINODE CONTROLLER_HOSTS COMPUTE_HOSTS SUBNODES_SSH_KEY TEST_OVERCLOUD_DELETE OVERCLOUD OSINFRA UNDERCLOUD_SANITY_CHECK OVERCLOUD_PINGTEST_ARGS FEATURE_BRANCH OVERCLOUD_ROLES UPGRADE_RELEASE OVERCLOUD_MAJOR_UPGRADE MAJOR_UPGRADE UNDERCLOUD_MAJOR_UPGRADE CA_SERVER UNDERCLOUD_TELEMETRY UNDERCLOUD_UI UNDERCLOUD_VALIDATIONS PREDICTABLE_PLACEMENT OPSTOOLS_REPO_ENABLED UPGRADE_ENV BOOTSTRAP_SUBNODES_MINIMAL MULTINODE_ENV_PATH; do if [ -n "${!VAR:+x}" ]; then echo "export $VAR=\"${!VAR}\"" >> $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-ci/deploy.env fi done for role in $OVERCLOUD_ROLES; do eval hosts=\${${role}_hosts} echo "export ${role}_hosts=\"${hosts}\"" >> $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-ci/deploy.env done }

commit_message:
Fix validations_inputs temporary file name

All the validations were failing when running through Mistral with a
`sudo` command not allowed issue [1] due to a typo in the file name.

This patch fixes the name of the temporary files containing potential
ansible variables.

[1] mistral : command not allowed ; TTY=unknown ; PWD=/ ; USER=root
 ; COMMAND=/usr/bin/chown -h validations: /tmp/validation_inputs_PoJRZa

Change-Id: I6699bbbab5cb15a8fd200c144a3d575e9f29ca37
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use the 'real' name for the LXC image

The Open Build Service repository for the Leap 15.0 LXC image returns
a metalink which causes aria2c to download 2 files. The first is an
empty file (the metalink) and the second is the actual LXC image. The
name of the second file changes frequently.

This change uses the `--on-download-complete` callback of aria2c to
call a helper script which links the expected filename to the actual
filename.

Change-Id: I9a2bc7ded20f772af82956a81a9864c7ee17039c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/74/658774/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove prevent-arp-spoofing warning messages.

This patch removes prevent-arp-spoofing warning log messages when it is
set to true, and the OpenStack release is >= ocata. It does not remove
the configuration option itself.

Change-Id: Ida1d67331e6d2df3d88d782125b8914f7dea5704
Closes-Bug: 1754386

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-17 11:26:22.000000000', 'files': ['nova/scheduler/manager.py', 'nova/cells/manager.py', 'nova/console/manager.py', 'nova/consoleauth/manager.py', 'nova/network/manager.py', 'nova/conductor/manager.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a3aed9a615ed5afd5205f5a2a1b624d06a6ded21', 'message': 'WIP: Initial prototype for simple RPC health checks

Some frameworks (like kubernetes) would benefit from having a chance
to find out at least basic state of a service by sending an RPC call.

This is an idea of just a primitive methods residing in server side of
the RPC API. Such simple method might be already good enough for basic
health check, as clients (created by health probes) can call it and

Example: see https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/49b58b7e7d51ac9fc793512a2a26403ac6af65e3

commit_message:
WIP: Initial prototype for simple RPC health checks

Some frameworks (like kubernetes) would benefit from having a chance
to find out at least basic state of a service by sending an RPC call.

This is an idea of just a primitive methods residing in server side of
the RPC API. Such simple method might be already good enough for basic
health check, as clients (created by health probes) can call it and
make sure the service is alive.

This could continue with adding some more elaborate checks in future.

Example: see https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/49b58b7e7d51ac9fc793512a2a26403ac6af65e3
for a change where nova health probe was introduced in openstack-helm.

Change-Id: Icfaccb11d871bc3c1be0d3e2e1cfee49fafe3655
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/653406/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-ceilometer refs/changes/18/659518/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Team and repository tags ======================== [![Team and repository tags](https://governance.openstack.org/badges/monasca-ceilometer.svg)](https://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/index.html) <!-- Change things from this point on --> monasca-ceilometer ======== Python plugin and storage driver for Ceilometer to send samples to monasca-api ### Installation instructions for setting up Ceilosca automatically See devstack/README.md ### Installation Instructions for setting up Ceilosca manually *To set up ceilosca automatically, read the instructions in devstack/README.md or use the included Vagrantfile* Assumes that an active monasca-api server is running. 1. Run devstack to get openstack installed. 2. Install python-monascaclient pip install python-monascaclient 3. Clone monasca-ceilometer from github.com. Copy the following files from *ceilosca/ceilometer* to devstack's ceilometer location typically at /opt/stack/ceilometer monasca_client.py storage/impl_monasca.py tests/* (skipping the init.py files) publisher/monasca_data_filter.py publisher/monclient.py ceilosca_mapping/* 4. Edit entry_points.txt Under [ceilometer.publisher] section add the following line: monasca = ceilometer.publisher.monclient:MonascaPublisher Under [ceilometer.metering.storage] section add the following line: monasca = ceilometer.storage.impl_monasca:Connection 5. Edit setup.cfg (used at the time of installation) Under 'ceilometer.publisher =' section add the following line: monasca = ceilometer.publisher.monclient:MonascaPublisher Under 'ceilometer.metering.storage =' section add the following line monasca = ceilometer.storage.impl_monasca:Connection 6. Configure /etc/ceilometer/pipeline.yaml to send the metrics to the monasca publisher. Use the included monasca-ceilometer/etc/ceilometer/pipeline.yaml file as an example. 7. Configure /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf for setting up storage driver for ceilometer API. Use the included monasca-ceilometer/etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf file as an example. 8. Copy the included monasca_field_definitions.yml and monasca_pipeline.yaml files from monasca-ceilometer/etc/ceilometer to /etc/ceilometer. This monasca_field_definitions.yaml file contains configuration how to treat each field in ceilometer sample object on per meter basis. The monasca_data_filter.py uses this file and only stores the fields that are specified in this config file. 9. Make sure the user specified under service_credentials in ceilometer.conf has *monasca_user role* added. ### Other info Since we don't have full repo of ceilometer, we setup the ceilometer repo in venv and copy monasca integration files in there, and run the unit tests over that code. At present this is tested against ceilometer stable/liberty branch, if you need to test against different branch you can change it in test-requirements.txt Relevant files are: monasca_test_setup.py - determines the ceilometer venv path and copies the relevant files over tox.ini - calls the commands for setup and runs the tests test-requirements.txt - contains the dependencies required for testing # License Copyright (c) 2015-2017 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-ui refs/changes/29/659529/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Team and repository tags ======================== [![Team and repository tags](https://governance.openstack.org/badges/monasca-ui.svg)](https://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/index.html) <!-- Change things from this point on --> monasca-ui ========== Monasca UI is implemented as a horizon plugin that adds panels to horizon. It is installed into devstack by monasca-vagrant. #Deployment Set Up * git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/horizon.git # clone horizon * cd horizon * Add git+https://git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-ui.git to requirements.txt * Edit openstack_dashboard/settings.py to include the following two lines: * import monitoring.enabled * monitoring.enabled, #Add to the settings.update_dashboards list #Development Environment Set Up ##Get the Code ``` git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-ui.git # clone monasca-ui git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/horizon.git # clone horizon git clone https://github.com/twc-openstack/grafana.git # clone grafana git clone https://github.com/twc-openstack/grafana-plugins.git # clone grafana plugins ``` ##Set up Horizon Since Monasca UI is a horizon plugin the first step is to get their development environment set up. ``` cd horizon ./run_tests.sh cp openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py ``` Pro Tip: Make sure you have horizon running correctly before proceeding. For more details go to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/quickstart.html#setup ##Set up Monasca-UI * Edit openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py to modify the OPENSTACK_HOST IP address to point to devstack. * Add monasca-client to requirements.txt. Get the latest version from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-monascaclient * Link monasca into Horizon: ``` ln -sf $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring/enabled/_50_admin_add_monitoring_panel.py \ $(pwd)/openstack_dashboard/enabled/_50_admin_add_monitoring_panel.py ln -sf $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring/conf/monitoring_policy.json \ $(pwd)/openstack_dashboard/conf/monitoring_policy.json ln -sfF $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring $(pwd)/monitoring ./run_tests #load monasca-client into virtualenv ``` ##Set up Grafana 2.6 * The v2.6.0-keystone branch of grafana is stable, as is v2.6.0 in grafana-plugins * Copy grafana-plugins/datasources/monasca into the grafana/public/app/plugins/datasource/ * Use the grafana docs to build and deploy grafana * http://docs.grafana.org/project/building_from_source/ * http://docs.grafana.org/installation/configuration/ * Copy monasca-ui/grafana-dashboards/* to /public/dashboards/ in your grafana deployment. * Set GRAFANA_URL in the horizon settings ##Start Server ``` ./run_tests.sh --runserver ``` ##Removing notification panel If you want to disable the notification panel copy over _70_remove_monasca_notification_panel to the openstack_dashboard/enabled directory #License Copyright (c) 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License.

deleted_lines: Team and repository tags ======================== [![Team and repository tags](https://governance.openstack.org/badges/monasca-ui.svg)](https://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/index.html) <!-- Change things from this point on --> monasca-ui ========== Monasca UI is implemented as a horizon plugin that adds panels to horizon. It is installed into devstack by monasca-vagrant. #Deployment Set Up * git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/horizon.git # clone horizon * cd horizon * Add git+https://git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-ui.git to requirements.txt * Edit openstack_dashboard/settings.py to include the following two lines: * import monitoring.enabled * monitoring.enabled, #Add to the settings.update_dashboards list #Development Environment Set Up ##Get the Code ``` git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-ui.git # clone monasca-ui git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/horizon.git # clone horizon git clone https://github.com/twc-openstack/grafana.git # clone grafana git clone https://github.com/twc-openstack/grafana-plugins.git # clone grafana plugins ``` ##Set up Horizon Since Monasca UI is a horizon plugin the first step is to get their development environment set up. ``` cd horizon ./run_tests.sh cp openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py ``` Pro Tip: Make sure you have horizon running correctly before proceeding. For more details go to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/quickstart.html#setup ##Set up Monasca-UI * Edit openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py to modify the OPENSTACK_HOST IP address to point to devstack. * Add monasca-client to requirements.txt. Get the latest version from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-monascaclient * Link monasca into Horizon: ``` ln -sf $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring/enabled/_50_admin_add_monitoring_panel.py \ $(pwd)/openstack_dashboard/enabled/_50_admin_add_monitoring_panel.py ln -sf $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring/conf/monitoring_policy.json \ $(pwd)/openstack_dashboard/conf/monitoring_policy.json ln -sfF $(pwd)/../monasca-ui/monitoring $(pwd)/monitoring ./run_tests #load monasca-client into virtualenv ``` ##Set up Grafana 2.6 * The v2.6.0-keystone branch of grafana is stable, as is v2.6.0 in grafana-plugins * Copy grafana-plugins/datasources/monasca into the grafana/public/app/plugins/datasource/ * Use the grafana docs to build and deploy grafana * http://docs.grafana.org/project/building_from_source/ * http://docs.grafana.org/installation/configuration/ * Copy monasca-ui/grafana-dashboards/* to /public/dashboards/ in your grafana deployment. * Set GRAFANA_URL in the horizon settings ##Start Server ``` ./run_tests.sh --runserver ``` ##Removing notification panel If you want to disable the notification panel copy over _70_remove_monasca_notification_panel to the openstack_dashboard/enabled directory #License Copyright (c) 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. commit_message:
Enable kolla-ansible to customize policy configurations in Ceilometer

We wanted/needed to customize the resource archiving policies in
 ceilometer, and to do that, we needed to use a custom file (instead
 of overwriting the default one). That is why we enabled this process
 on Kolla-ansible

 Kolla-ansible did not provide support to customize that file
 "gnocchi_resources.yaml". Therefore, this PR adds this "feature"
 to it (kolla-ansible) by adding a method to manage
 "custom_gnocchi_resources.yaml" file.

Change-Id: If939345f4d6bf2bf1b32ee532e3435b026043975
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

commit_message:
Fix subnet host_routes error

When updating subnet with "no-host-route" option, set host_routes to an empty list as neutron_lib.api.validators expected.

Change-Id: I6fe039793d813758429c7a104fd40172b4f8122b
Closes-Bug: #1747101

commit_message:
Add spec for Data Jobs table

As Share Migration feature is introduced and other "job-like" features are in
the roadmap, such as Share Backup, it creates the need to track and maintain
them as jobs, as they can take unbounded amounts of time to complete.

This spec discusses the proposal of the Data Jobs table feature for
the Ocata release of OpenStack Manila.

APIImpact

Change-Id: I0853d61393bdaab793d529b7cc34e7f4cddd7a27
Partially-implements: blueprint data-service-jobs-table
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-specs refs/changes/62/392262/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== Data Jobs Table =============== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/manila/+spec/data-service-jobs-table As Share Migration feature is introduced and other "job-like" features are in the roadmap, such as Share Backup, it creates the need to track and maintain them as jobs, as they can take unbounded amounts of time to complete. Problem description =================== Currently, whenever share migration operations are started, they are sent either to the Data Service or the driver to be performed without being individually tracked. This creates the following problems: * There is no limit on how many share migrations can be started, this allows the possibility to create hundreds of share migration operations and effectively not completing any of them, because the Data Service (for the host-assisted approach) and drivers (for the driver-assisted approach) will accept and start them immediately. The default workflow for administrators becomes to wait for requests to complete and start new ones manually, as there is no way to enqueue them. This increases the need of writing scripts. * Once a share migration has been completed, cancelled or failed, the result is written to the logs and a 'task_state' field value is set to the involved share model. This value is lost when a new share migration is started, so if there are scripts watching and processing batch operations on shares (such as a backup and then a migration), it will be up to the scripts to record the results. * Manila services are supposed to be as stateless as possible. Currently, whenever a share migration is started, the request information sent by the administrator, which comprises of API parameter values, are not saved, preventing manila from being able to restart it. This is also required for HA deployments where running operations need to be transferred to other Active nodes when a failure occurs. In the other hand, drivers are able to save the information in the driver's private storage, but it is customized and restricted to the drivers, thus not being suited to be handled by manila in a failover scenario. * Whenever a migration is running, the administrator may query for progress. Currently, the requests are sent directly to the Data Service or drivers to compute the progress. This creates additional workload on the manila-data or manila-share based on the polling ratio of these progress requests. This workload should be handled by the API and Database which are designed to scale and be load-balanced accordingly. * Currently, multiple Data Service may be spawned, but their operations are not coordinated and there is no way to know which operations each data service is performing, which ends up being cumbersome to have to write down notes to keep track of that information. At certain points, an administrator may want to perform maintenance on a Data Service node and needs to know which are busy and which shares have operations running on that Data Service. Use Cases ========= The implementation of the Jobs table addresses existing problems and introduces new use cases as seen below: * Enqueue job operations * Configure number of simultaneous running jobs * List current jobs * View progress of each job * View which jobs are running on each data service * View previous jobs' results * Scale jobs in HA Proposed change =============== This change proposes adding: * Add new tables to the database, named "Jobs" and JobDetails" (see Data model impact section). * A config option in the Data Service to set the number of concurrent jobs for that manila-data node. * Add Database APIs to create, update, get and delete entries from the tables above. * New APIs to list and show jobs (See REST API impact section). * Change Share Migration "migration-get-progress" API code to retrieve progress from the database instead of creating a RPC call to manila-data or manila-share. * Change Share Migration to create a job database entry when a request arrives in the manila-share service. * Change Share Migration host-assisted approach to send a RPC request to manila-data to start the job. * Change Share Migration driver-assisted approach to maintain the job it during migration. * Change Share model 'task_state' field behavior to contain the same value as the 'job_status' of latest running job. Alternatives ------------ Do not implement what is proposed in this spec and leave to administrator to workaround the problems presented through scripting. Data model impact ----------------- The impact will consist of a database migration that changes the following: * Add empty "Jobs" table. Fields: - id: job UUID - job_state: a status string - type: type of job - host: name of service host running the job - created_at: timestamp of entry creation - started_at timestamp of job start - completed_at: timestamp of job completion - deleted_at: timestamp of entry deletion - deleted: boolean True/False * Add empty "JobDetails" table. Fields: - id: job request data UUID. - job_id: foreign key job UUID to which this request data relates to - key: key of request data - value: value of request data - created_at: timestamp of entry creation - deleted_at: timestamp of entry deletion - deleted: boolean True/False * Add nullable foreign key 'job_id' to "Shares" table. The database API will have the following new methods: * job_create * job_delete * job_update * job_get * job_get_all REST API impact --------------- * Add the Jobs controller with GET methods, updating the API router * Add the following User-facing API: - Get all jobs:: Method = GET URL = /jobs/detail Response codes: 200 for success, 400 for invalid parameters. View columns: id, job_state, type, host, created_at, started_at, completed_at Filter parameters: type, job_state, host, enqueued (started_at and completed_at are empty), running (started_at is not empty but completed_at is) completed (completed_at is not empty) Response body: { "id": "<id>", "job_state": "<job_state>", "type": "<type>", "host": "<host>", "created_at": "<created_at>", "started_at": "<started_at>", "completed_at": "<completed_at>", "progress": progress } * Add the following Admin-facing API: - Get job data:: Method = GET URL = /jobs/{job_id} Response codes: 200 for success, 400 for invalid parameters. Response body: { "id": "<id>", "job_state": "<job_state>", "type": "<type>", "host": "<host>", "created_at": "<created_at>", "started_at": "<started_at>", "completed_at": "<completed_at>", "progress": progress, "deleted_at": "<deleted_at>", "deleted": <True/False>, "details": ["<details key: value>"] } * Bump microversion to the next available one Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- This feature will be available in python-manilaclient. See commands:: manila data-jobs-list [--type] [--job_state] [--host] [--enqueued|--running|--completed] manila data-jobs-show <job_id> Performance impact ------------------ Performance is expected to improve when doing several concurrent migrations while having the administrators polling for migration progress. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers of other "job-like" features such as Share Backup should become acquainted with the Data Jobs table to adapt the features for it. As part of this proposal, the existing Share Migration code is going to be adapted for it. Driver impact ------------- This will impact the current driver interfaces for the driver-assisted migration approach of Share Migration. The migration_continue return value will be changed from 'boolean' to 'boolean, dict' where the dictionary returned will include information that was previously returned on migration_get_progress driver interface, which will cease to exist. This proposal will incorporate the changes to the drivers that already implement driver-assisted migration. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ganso Work Items ---------- * Implement main patch for manila that includes: - Tempest tests - Unit tests - Database migration - Database API new entries and updates - Share migration host-assisted and driver-assisted changes * Implement additions and changes in python-manilaclient with: - Unit tests - Functional tests where applicable * Create documentation for this feature (see below) Dependencies ============ No previous dependencies on other ocata patches so far Testing ======= - Unit tests - Tempest tests Documentation Impact ==================== - Docstrings - Release notes - Devref - User-guide - Admin-guide References ========== [1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ocata-manila-data-service-jobs-table

commit_message:
Add spec for Data Service API

With the introduction of the Data Service in Mitaka, rises the
possibility of allowing an user to request the Data Service to
copy data between shares (or snapshots, if they are mountable),
which may be more efficient than manually doing it.

Change-Id: Ia52bd858f4be1662419a31c6c629199b3c5ccd66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-specs refs/changes/09/315709/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================== Data Service API ======================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/manila/+spec/data-service-api The Data Service is responsible for performing various tasks that involve handling in or between shares. Currently it is available only to Manila internal code. Its functionality could be used for the end user perform data copy between shares more efficiently. Problem description =================== If an end user wants to copy data between two shares, he would mount the two shares and execute a command that copies data. This essentially takes a very long time, since data is often downloaded to the end user's machine and uploaded again to the new share, which becomes even slower as the network latency between the end user's machine and the server increases. This could be prevented if data was copied in the cloud itself, through the admin network or in the backend itself. Use Cases ========= There are some scenarios for which a user may want to use the Data Service API: * Copy data efficiently from a share or mountable snapshot to another share. * Delete a tree of folders containing data without having to mount the share. * Make a script that calls Manila API for backup instead of doing it manually. Proposed change =============== For the first version, no driver interfaces will be introduced, at first this should use the Data Service only as experimental API. Add APIs: 1) data-copy [--snapshot <snapshot-id>] <source_share_id> <source_path> <destination_share_id> <destination_path> snapshot: copy data from a mountable snapshot instead of share. source_share_id: the id of the share from which data will be copied. source_path: the path of data to be copied. destination_share_id: the id of the share to which data will be copied. destination_path: the path where data should be copied to. 2) data-erase <share_id> <path> share_id: the id of the share from which data will be erased. path: the path of data to be erased. 3) data-copy-get-progress <share> share: share from which data copy progress should be obtained. Data copy job must be in 'data_copy_in_progress' to have its progress obtained. 4) data-copy-cancel <share> share: share from which data-copy should be cancelled. Data copy job must be in 'data_copy_in_progress' to be cancellable. Alternatives ------------ Do not have the feature implemented and administrator would need to do this manually and less efficiently. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Two user-facing new API methods are introduced: 1) (POST, 202) data-copy: copies data from a share or snapshot to another share 2) (POST, 202) data-erase: erases data from a share 3) (POST, 202) data-copy-get-progress <share> 4) (POST, 202) data-copy-cancel <share> Security impact --------------- In order to access a share's data, it must be mounted by an entity. The entity mounting the share is responsible for the data. During migration, if the fallback approach is used, the Data Service will be mounting the migrating share and copying data, thus it will expose the share's contents to the Data Service node during a limited period of time. The Data Service is accessible through the administrator network, thus it grants access to data to whoever is able to connect to the Data Service. Restricted access to this node is advised. Also, an option to disable migration will be included for security-sensitive cloud environments. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Same as Share Migration's. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None at this time Implementation ============== Upon receiving the API request to start a data operation, the Share API layer will perform the following validations: Check share's status: - If not available, return error. Check if share is busy with another task: - If busy, return error. It will then set the task_state to DATA_COPY_IN_PROGRESS and proceed to invoke the Data Service RPC API to perform the copy. Status is not changed and other share operations are not blocked. Upon completion, the task_state will be changed to DATA_COPY_COMPLETED. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ganso Work Items ---------- - Implement changes agreed in this spec, possibly in a single patch. Dependencies ============ Share Migration Data Service Testing ======= - Standard unit tests - Tempest tests Documentation Impact ==================== The new APIs will be documented. References ========== Newton design summit etherpad discussion: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-manila-data-service-migration

commit_message:
Add spec for Share Retype

Share Retype feature was briefly discussed in Mitaka Midcycle
and briefly discussed again in Newton Summit. We agreed to propose
a spec to discuss the design.

This is a feature that is dependent on Share Migration, where a
user may retype a share, which can be performed by the driver
in the same backend, or require the share to be migrated.

Change-Id: I1598854680a172a0f50c4591b316babdaeda88f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-specs refs/changes/08/315708/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================== Share Retype ======================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/manila/+spec/share-retype Share retype is a feature that allows an user to change a share's type through the API. A share type is a grouping of extra-specs that are used to define a share's characteristics and its compatibility with a certain backend. Changing a share's type to another one with different extra-specs may involve having to re-create a share in a different backend and move its contents, since some characteristics are intrinsic to the share and cannot be changed. Problem description =================== Currently, once a share is created using a certain type, it cannot be changed. The user may want to change a share's type for several reasons (see use cases). There are a few ways to change a share's type entry without the proper retype feature, such as editing the extra-specs in the type definition, or unmanaging a share and managing with a different share type. Neither of those approaches are available to the end user or are advisable to be used, other than workarounds a knowledgeable admin can perform. Use Cases ========= There are some scenarios for which a user may want to retype a share: * Promote or Demote a share (Bronze to Silver, Silver to Bronze). * Add or remove capabilities from his share. Proposed change =============== This spec aims to propose the Share Retype design, progressing on the design started at Austin Summit 2016. Consider the following scenarios: User triggers a retype: - New Share type fits same backend, driver may retype non-disruptively - New Share type fits same backend, driver may retype disruptively - New Share type does not fit same backend, share is migrated See "Implementation" section to see how these scenarios are addressed. Add APIs: 1) retype-start [--disruption-policy <nondisruptive|local_disruptive|migrate>] [--finish] [--lossy] [--writeable] <share> <new-type> finish (defaults True): whether retype should complete in 1-step, or if 2-phase retype should be used. Drivers should respect this parameter. lossy (defaults False): whether retype should allow the possibility of losing metadata. If set to False, this will prevent fallback migration from running. Drivers should respect this parameter. writeable (defaults to True): whether retype should only be performed if share remains writable. If set to True, this will prevent fallback approach from running. Drivers should respect this parameter. disruption-policy: The disruption policy the user allows. 'nondisruptive' value specifies that retype should be performed only if there can be no disruption. 'local_disruptive' value specifies that disruption is allowed but the user does not want to migrate the share. Finally, 'migrate' values specifies that migration is allowed if necessary to retype the share. Drivers should respect this parameter. share: share to be moved. new-type: the type the share's type should be change to. 2) retype-complete <share> share: share on which retype should be completed. Retype job must be in 'retype_driver_phase1_complete', 'data_copying_complete' or 'migration_driver_phase1_complete' to have its phase 2 retype invoked. 3) retype-get-progress <share> share: share from which retype progress should be obtained. Retype job must be in 'retype_driver_in_progress' or 'data_copy_in_progress' to have its progress obtained. 4) retype-cancel <share> share: share from which retype should be cancelled. Retype job must be in 'retype_driver_in_progress' or 'data_copy_in_progress' to be cancellable. Add driver interfaces: def retype_start(self, context, share_ref, share_server, new_type, diff, finish, writeable, lossy): """Is called to perform 1st phase of driver retype of a given share. Driver should implement this method if willing to perform retype in an optimized way. :param context: The 'context.RequestContext' object for the request. :param share_ref: Reference to the share being retyped. :param share_server: Share server model or None. :param new_type: The type to be retyped to and its extra-specs. :param diff: The extra-spec difference between the current and new types. :param finish: whether the retype should complete or wait for 2nd phase call. Driver may throw exception when validating this parameter, exception if does not support 1-step or 2-phase approach. :param lossy: whether the user allowed a lossy retype to be performed. :param writeable: whether the user requires the share to remain writeable. :returns: Boolean value indicating if driver migration succeeded. :returns: Dictionary containing a model update with relevant data to be updated after retype, such as export locations. """ returns None, None by default. def retype_complete(self, context, share_ref, share_server, new_type, diff): """Is called to perform 2nd phase of driver retype of a given share. If driver is implementing 2-phase retype, this method should perform tasks related to the 2nd phase of retype, thus completing it. :param context: The 'context.RequestContext' object for the request. :param share_ref: Reference to the share being retyped. :param share_server: Share server model or None. :param new_type: The type to be retyped to and its extra-specs. :param diff: The extra-spec difference between the current and new types. :returns: Dictionary containing a model update with relevant data to be updated after retype, such as export locations. """ returns None by default. def retype_cancel(self, context, share_ref, share_server): """Is called to cancel driver retype. If possible, driver can implement a way to cancel an in-progress retype. :param context: The 'context.RequestContext' object for the request. :param share_ref: Reference to the share being retyped. :param share_server: Share server model or None. """ throws NotImplementedError(). def retype_get_progress(self, context, share_ref, share_server): """Is called to get retype progress. If possible, driver can implement a way to return retype progress information. :param context: The 'context.RequestContext' object for the request. :param share_ref: Reference to the share being retyped. :param share_server: Share server model or None. :return: A dictionary with 'total_progress' field containing the percentage value. """ throws NotImplementedError(). Alternatives ------------ Do not have the feature implemented and administrator would need to do this manually and less efficiently. Multiple cloud providers would need to create scripts for doing this and handling each failure scenario themselves. This spec proposes a common way of doing this. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Five user-facing new API methods are introduced: 1) (POST, 202) retype-start: retypes share 2) (POST, 202) retype-complete: triggers 2nd phase of 2-phase retype 3) (POST, 202) retype-get-progress: attempts to obtain retype progress 4) (POST, 202) retype-cancel: attempts to cancel retype Security impact --------------- In order to access a share's data, it must be mounted by an entity. The entity mounting the share is responsible for the data. During migration, if the fallback approach is used, the Data Service will be mounting the migrating share and copying data, thus it will expose the share's contents to the Data Service node during a limited period of time. The Data Service is accessible through the administrator network, thus it grants access to data to whoever is able to connect to the Data Service. Restricted access to this node is advised. Also, an option to disable migration will be included for security-sensitive cloud environments. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Users will be able to invoke retype through the python-manilaclient as well. Commands will be similar to the names proposed for the REST API and follow standardized python-manilaclient requirements. Performance Impact ------------------ Same as Share Migration's. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Vendors can implement the optimized retype in their drivers in order to retype data efficiently without requiring data to be migrated across backends. Implementation ============== Upon receiving the API request to retype a share, the Share API layer will perform the following validations: Check share's status: - If not available, return error. Check if new type is the same as current type: - if True, return error. Check if share is busy with another task: - If busy, return error. Check if share has replicas: - if True, return error. Migration has to support migrating shares with replicas before retype can support them as well. Check if share is member of a consistency group: - if True, return error. Migration has to support migrating shares members of replicas before retype can support them as well. Check if there are snapshots: - If there are, return error. Migration has to support migrating shares with snaphots before retype can support them as well. If all validations succeed, it should set task_state to RETYPE_STARTING and invoke the scheduler asynchronously to validate if the current host supports the new share type. If current host validation fails, the scheduler will try to find another host for the share. If no host can be found, it will set task_state to RETYPE_ERROR (no notification). Else it will invoke the share's manager also asynchronously to proceed with retype. At the share manager, it will change the share's task_state to RETYPE_IN_PROGRESS and instance status to RETYPING. If host received from scheduler is the same, it will proceed with driver retyping. Else, it will start a migration according to the disruption policy parameter. If proceeding with driver retype, invoke driver's retype method. The driver is expected to return two values, a boolean which indicates if the operation was successful and a model update. Depending on the "finish" parameter, the task_state is set to either RETYPE_SUCCESS or RETYPE_PHASE1_DONE, respectively related to 1-step or 2-phase retype. If any exception is thrown or if the driver returns that it has not successfully completed the operation, the disruption policy is analyzed in order to invoke migration accordingly. If a migration is invoked upon failing driver retype, only the fallback migration is invoked to perform migration to the same host, which consists of creating a new empty share and copying contents, if "writable" and "lossy" parameters allow such. The share's manager retype-complete method will first check the retyping share's task_state value to decide whether to invoke the driver's retype_complete method or migration one, succeeded by a task_state update to RETYPE_SUCCESS. The driver is expected to perform the last disruptive steps of retype and return a model update. The retype-cancel and retype-get-progress calls will attempt to cancel and obtain progress, respectively, if applicable. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ganso Work Items ---------- - Implement changes agreed in this spec, possibly in a single patch. Dependencies ============ Share Migration Data Service Testing ======= - Standard unit tests - Tempest tests Documentation Impact ==================== The new APIs will be documented. Driver interfaces will include docstrings. References ========== Newton design summit etherpad discussion: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-manila-data-service-migration

commit_message:
Add multipath to nova-compute AppArmor profile

Deploying nova-compute with apparmor in enforce mode causes it to fail
to attach volumes with multipath. This patch fixes it by updating the
nova-compute apparmor profile to include paths and binaries needed for
multipath.

Change-Id: Icc2d187fa3dd63e0930d57a87e7a60ff386f0032
Closes-bug: #1826467

subject: Drop systemd support from PAM
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-05-08 14:10:44.000000000', 'files': ['docker/base/Dockerfile.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/c56ee10d21496f0d1e8f2757226526686f524c21', 'message': 'Drop systemd support from PAM

The line being removed is the cause of audit.log spam with a
SELinux enforcing (and permissive) system. They are due to the
fact we're calling "sudo" from within some containers, and PAM
wants to connect to the host "dbus" socket (mounted in /run).
This action is obviously denied by SELinux.

The "-" prefix makes this module optional anyway, but apparently
PAM does see it and tries to use it.

Dropping this module has no consequences other than preventing
log spamming.

Change-Id: I3e0e86026f5a4a78473bed824cd1682d3a020cd5
Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <mbaldess@redhat.com>
Resolves-Bug: #1819461
(cherry picked from commit c4b62490714ea849cedfe07d4b9a6aebf1f815c0)
'}]
commit_message:
Drop systemd support from PAM

The line being removed is the cause of audit.log spam with a
SELinux enforcing (and permissive) system. They are due to the
fact we're calling "sudo" from within some containers, and PAM
wants to connect to the host "dbus" socket (mounted in /run).
This action is obviously denied by SELinux.

The "-" prefix makes this module optional anyway, but apparently
PAM does see it and tries to use it.

Dropping this module has no consequences other than preventing
log spamming.

Change-Id: I3e0e86026f5a4a78473bed824cd1682d3a020cd5
Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <mbaldess@redhat.com>
Resolves-Bug: #1819461
(cherry picked from commit c4b62490714ea849cedfe07d4b9a6aebf1f815c0)

commit_message:
Prepare OSA release for Stein

This bumps the projects shas to their HEAD of their
stable/stein branch. Some projects have branched
since the last bump, so this patch also make sure
the correct branch is tracked.

It also ensures the roles are properly frozen, and
can follow the usual 2 week's bumping process.

Change-Id: I038354c5e55ed9440c2116e4291cf09b78734c6d

Increasing this value can increase the performances during the queues/exchanges/bindings creation/destroying. The values should be between 100 and 1000. More detail [1]. [1] http://erlang.org/doc/man/mnesia.html#dump_log_write_threshold

commit_message:
Fix NovaNfs role parameter precedence in conditions

I2702a022565a130ab339d165cb2252ad67d1162e changed the Nova NFS params to be
role specific, however the global param still takes precedence in the
enable_live_migration_tunnelled condition.
With this change the the global param is only considered when the role
specific param is not set.

Change-Id: I3d1a0f632e8a7e4924ebabdc795c0ef5d53cdd6d
Related-Bug: 1823712
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/11/659111/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - and: - equals: [{get_param: NovaNfsEnabled}, true] - equals: [{get_param: [RoleParameters, NovaNfsEnabled]}, '']

commit_message:
[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

This patch also sets up the mode for the /etc/mysql directory
to be 755 for things to work.  We should lock that down eventually
for only the MySQL user.

Change-Id: I2e9ee987a353a28da00cd37cbdb82ec46ccc414c

commit_message:
Add hostname as a new config option

Without this option, the charm announces its API URL with the VIP
address. It is problematic when using FQDN in the SAN section of the
certificates and not IP addresses.

Change-Id: Id40f7f3d70c1e9b055bd0ed65c1c9a90c95f84c1
Closes-Bug: 1826225

added_lines: if config('hostname'): vault_url = vault.get_api_url(address=config('hostname')) else: vault_url = vault.get_api_url(address=config('vip'))

correctly.

commit_message:
Update fwaas configuration for user-defined L3 Agents

The stock L3 Agent of Neutron defines the attribute router_distributed
which is directly used by FWaaS. However, if the user uses any other L3
agent, then it is possible that the attribute router_distributed isn't
defined. Therefore FWaaS config now allows setting the
router_distributed attribute to avoid the issue.

This attribute is not requried when using the default L3 agent of neutron.

Closes-Bug: #1597132
Change-Id: I9cad2460fb4f8baf71122c101bfdaa88c3b4977b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas refs/changes/63/501663/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- other: - | ``router_distributed=True`` needs to be mentioned in the ``neutron_fwaas`` config file, only if the routers used are distributed and the L3 agent is not the OVS(Stock) L3 Agent of Neutron. The default value of ``router_distributed`` is False.

subject: don't change ownership of empty OSD directories
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-10 01:13:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charms.ceph/commit/669feb7f4623a65eeda7cb5006135c35b893e865', 'message': 'don't change ownership of empty OSD directories

dirs_need_ownership_update detects when OSD directories require an
ownership change from root to ceph. However if an OSD directory exists,
but the OSD is not yet mounted, then the directory is expected to be
owned by root.

This may happen if an OSD is stopped or the OSD is no longer in use,
including on reboot when the OSD may not yet be started before the
config_changed hook runs.

The logic in check_for_upgrade uses this check to decide if a previous
upgrade failed, then incorrectly tries to resume an upgrade that never
existed. This will cause the charm to get stuck forever inside of the
config_changed hook on reboot with the following juju status:
"Waiting on <host> to finish upgrading"

This will fix the majority of such cases, however some corner cases may
still exist and further improvements need to be made to the
check_for_upgrade resume logic (LP #1823822)

Change-Id: If9d7e5bcfc0b1f152643a14432e76572ac14a812
Closes-Bug: #1779828

commit_message:
don't change ownership of empty OSD directories

dirs_need_ownership_update detects when OSD directories require an
ownership change from root to ceph. However if an OSD directory exists,
but the OSD is not yet mounted, then the directory is expected to be
owned by root.

This may happen if an OSD is stopped or the OSD is no longer in use,
including on reboot when the OSD may not yet be started before hooks
run.

Change-Id: If9d7e5bcfc0b1f152643a14432e76572ac14a812
Partial-Bug: #1779828
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charms.ceph refs/changes/15/651415/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(lathiat): when config_changed runs on reboot, the OSD might not # yet be mounted or started, and the underlying directory the OSD is # mounted to is expected to be owned by root. So skip the check. This # may also happen for OSD directories for OSDs that were removed. if (service == 'osd' and not os.path.exists(os.path.join(child, 'magic'))): continue

commit_message:
Add support for TaaS for OSC

Following patch adds support for OSC migration
of Tap-as-a-service client.

Change-Id: If06b7cb9bad4a584d84c5a305f94253f9e6ed826
Closes-Bug: #1565622

commit_message:
Add new protocols in Firewalls

Firewall rules can now also filter DCCP and
SCTP protocols.

Change-Id: I312f7f572dab33bd56b0edf395e0e076d3203f5f
Closes-Bug: #1669956

commit_message:
Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: Ib7f8df3fc5b83520b179d0a260c54e015c042b17
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

it there as well.

commit_message:
Add support for Ceilometer custom gnocchi_resources.yaml

By default, Ceilometer uses gnocchi_resources.yaml as cfg_file that defines
the metric archive policy and metrics send to gnocchi. Users may want to define
their own strategy.

Change-Id: I49ba34588101ac2b4f450067c8c9a354134063bb
Signed-off-by: Ning Yao <yaoning@unitedstack.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/81/653381/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: }{% endif %}{% if ceilometer_gnocchi_resources_file_path is defined %}, { "source": "{{ container_config_directory }}/gnocchi_resources.yaml", "dest": "/etc/ceilometer/gnocchi_resources.yaml", "owner": "ceilometer", "perm": "0600"

commit_message:
Provide support for neutron dev mode in kolla

Add a possibility to mount sources as volumes to containers,
in "more than documentation" way. That will let us to use kolla
as a replacement for devstack.

Partially implements: blueprint mount-sources

Change-Id: I4868ed6829bd037e1012d1f40c4a1d1b9995bf95

subject: undercloud: resolve undercloud_*_host
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-05-10 06:55:00.000000000', 'files': ['tripleoclient/tests/test_utils.py', 'tripleoclient/v1/undercloud_config.py', 'tripleoclient/utils.py', 'tripleoclient/exceptions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/098fdb2cd912dabeeb40161edc6dd5df98940c31', 'message': "undercloud: resolve undercloud_*_host

The problem we're solving here is that our operators using SSL + FQDN
based endpoints will have failures during the deployment because we
don't lookup the FQDN into IP addresses, needed later in the deployment
for proper binding.

This patch transforms undercloud_*_host parameters into IP addresses:

- We raise if lookup returns nothing.
- We raise if lookup returns more than one IP.
- We support both IPv4 and IPv6.
- We raise if the IP is a loopback.
- We raise if the returned IP is invalid.

Utils changes:

* Introduce utils.is_valid_ip.
  Return True if the IP is either v4 or v6. Return False otherwise.

* Introduce utils.is_loopback.
  Return True if the given host is a loopback. Return False otherwise.

* Introduce utils.get_host_ips.
  Returns a list of IPs for a host to lookup.

* Introduce utils.get_single_ip.
  Translate an hostname or FQDN into an IP address if it is valid IP.
  Return it unchanged if it is an IPv4 or IPv6 address.
  If the host is not reachable, it'll raise an exception.
  By default it excludes the loopbacks but it can be allowed by setting
  allow_loopback = True.

* Use utils.get_single_ip to translate undercloud_admin_host and
  undercloud_public_host to IP addresses.

Related-Bug: #1763776
Change-Id: Ic008cc758493aa95e8aa237d23c2f66c0a930509
(cherry picked from commit c925c3b93bf02538c9308baf91aa0c7cc6dd20e9)
"}]
commit_message:
undercloud: resolve undercloud_*_host

The problem we're solving here is that our operators using SSL + FQDN
based endpoints will have failures during the deployment because we
don't lookup the FQDN into IP addresses, needed later in the deployment
for proper binding.

This patch transforms undercloud_*_host parameters into IP addresses:

- We raise if lookup returns nothing.
- We raise if lookup returns more than one IP.
- We support both IPv4 and IPv6.
- We raise if the IP is a loopback.
- We raise if the returned IP is invalid.

Utils changes:

* Introduce utils.is_valid_ip.
  Return True if the IP is either v4 or v6. Return False otherwise.

* Introduce utils.is_loopback.
  Return True if the given host is a loopback. Return False otherwise.

* Introduce utils.get_host_ips.
  Returns a list of IPs for a host to lookup.

* Introduce utils.get_single_ip.
  Translate an hostname or FQDN into an IP address if it is valid IP.
  Return it unchanged if it is an IPv4 or IPv6 address.
  If the host is not reachable, it'll raise an exception.
  By default it excludes the loopbacks but it can be allowed by setting
  allow_loopback = True.

* Use utils.get_single_ip to translate undercloud_admin_host and
  undercloud_public_host to IP addresses.

Related-Bug: #1763776
Change-Id: Ic008cc758493aa95e8aa237d23c2f66c0a930509
(cherry picked from commit c925c3b93bf02538c9308baf91aa0c7cc6dd20e9)

commit_message:
Remove HostEntryDeployment

This deployment was for getting the hostname of pre-provisioned nodes.
This is no longer required with config-download since a HostnameMap is
required to be used with config-download.

Change-Id: I35d7d03c5373a251dfe96c2f71c4915ee52f113a

commit_message:
Remove InstanceIdDeployment

This deployment is no longer needed as it was only setting metadata that
was used by os-collect-config. Now that config-download is used,
os-collect-config is no longer used, we can get rid of this deployment.

Change-Id: Icd45f7299c4053373b3161d90ad32135c9f40e5a

commit_message:
Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: I719a8cff50dcc0dea62db14edf7b9ab35b72facd
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

commit_message:
Move haproxy role tags to play

There is no need to distinguish between haproxy-config tasks and
haproxy.

* Move haproxy role tags to play.
* Remove the service tag from haproxy-config tasks

Change-Id: I0ae07373285b61f976930d4769ea83eae2863850
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

deleted_lines: Team and repository tags ======================== [![Team and repository tags](https://governance.openstack.org/badges/monasca-persister.svg)](https://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/index.html) <!-- Change things from this point on --> monasca-persister ============= The Monitoring Persister consumes metrics and alarm state transitions from the Message Queue and stores them in the Metrics and Alarms database. Although the Persister isn't primarily a Web service it uses DropWizard, https://dropwizard.github.io/dropwizard/, which provides a nice Web application framework to expose an http endpoint that provides an interface through which metrics about the Persister can be queried as well as health status. The basic design of the Persister is to have one Kafka consumer publish to a Disruptor, https://github.com/LMAX-Exchange/disruptor, that has output processors. The output processors use prepared batch statements to write to the Metrics and Alarms database. The number of output processors/threads in the Persister can be specified to scale to more messages. To horizontally scale and provide fault-tolerance any number of Persisters can be started as consumers from the Message Queue. # Build Requires monasca-common from https://github.com/openstack/monasca-common. Download and build following instructions in its README.md. Then build monasca-persister by: ``` mvn clean package ``` # Configuration A sample configuration file is available in java/src/deb/etc/persister-config.yml-sample. A second configuration file is provided in java/src/main/resources/persister-config.yml for use with the [vagrant "mini-mon" development environment](https://github.com/openstack/monasca-vagrant/). # TODO * Purge metrics on shutdown * Add more robust offset management in Kafka. Currently, the offset is advanced as each message is read. If the Persister stops after the metric has been read and prior to it being committed to the Metrics and Alarms database, the metric will be lost. * Add better handling of SQL exceptions. * Complete health check. * Specify and document the names of the metrics that are available for monitoring of the Persister. * Document the yaml configuration parameters. # License Copyright (c) 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. commit_message:
Add rcp_transport parameter for conductor

When Ironic Conductor requires optimizations over WAN, like some Edge
computing cases, allow configuring its [DEFAULT] rpc_transport setting.
F.e. rpc_transport may be set to 'json-rpc' for Ironic conductor
instances running at the edge sites, when the used messaging broker
should not be stretched over WAN. For such cases, this option also
plays nicely alongside the [conductor] conductor_group setting.

Related-Blueprint: undercloud-minion

Change-Id: Iad2f73f730315e8b3f0d5d809458626c9ebc890e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/53/659053/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Adds ``ironic::conductor::rpc_transport`` parameter to define remote procedure call transport between conductor and API processes.

added_lines: nova_status_upgrade_check: start_order: 4 image: *nova_api_image net: host detach: false volumes: *nova_api_bootstrap_volumes user: root # NOTE(lyarwood): We can swallow return codes of 0 and 1 here as # the deployment/upgrade should still complete even when warnings, # such as the need for online migrations to complete, are listed. command: "/usr/bin/bootstrap_host_exec nova_api su nova -s /bin/bash -c '/usr/bin/nova-status upgrade check; ret=$?; if [ $ret -ne 0 ] || [ $ret -ne 1 ]; then exit $ret; else exit 0; fi'"

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: If9c46ca5a80128bb8c6a9bd9863c4c3305bae54c

commit_message:
Use upper constraints

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped python 2.7 and 3.4 support. Because osprofiler
uses global upper-constraints.txt only from Rocky,
job openstack-tox-py27 tries to install Sphinx 2.0.1 and fails [1] with:

 Downloading http://mirror.iad.rax.openstack.org/wheel/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/sphinx/Sphinx-2.0.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (3.2MB)
 ERROR: Sphinx requires Python '>=3.5' but the running Python is 2.7.12

Note: .[oslo.config] could be removed as the packages will be installed
perfectly and constrained without this and it breaks installation if
upper-constraints.txt is used anyway.

Note: patch adjusted to Pike

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/stable/queens/openstack-tox-py27/3d469d3/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-10_06_10_56_192617

Change-Id: Ife6bcaca347d914cb1fc7e2fe71665ea5c93ca80
(cherry picked from commit eff57e09b55aaf1f00b01c289526ceddefdf25d9)
